The Secret to Naming In-App¬†Currency

Leveraging the Currency Pyramid to make more¬†money.

Currency is fascinating.

People are willing to offer their time, trade their resources and reciprocate kindness or gratitude in exchange for it (think happy customer service).

There are so many different dimensions to currency and a curious question that pops up time and time again, revolves around the names.

Why is currency labelled and named in so many different ways?

Of course, there‚Äôs economic and sociocultural reasons why currency has (and still can) range from pounds to pesos or dollars to rupees, but there‚Äôs more to it than that.

Did you know that ‚Äòpeso‚Äô literally translates to ‚Äòweight‚Äô in Spanish? In context, weight only ever implies two things:

  1. That something is physically heavy
  2. That something has gravitas (importance)

Now, perhaps peso was a physically heavy currency when it was first created (it was metal after all) but it‚Äôs much more fascinating to assume that peso was named after the gravitas that it, as a currency holds.

From Real Life to Make¬†Believe

For the purpose of this article, this is the definition we‚Äôll use for In-App currency (IAC)‚Ä¶

In-App currency (IAC) is the fabricated currency tied to a specific app that allows users to purchase assets (items, perks and rewards).

IAC comes in 2 forms:

  • Simple¬†
    //IAC that‚Äôs earned easily within an app and used to trade for common assets. Simple IAC is the most readily available and easy to come by currency in an app.
  • Premium¬†
    //IAC that has increased rarity within an app and is often used to trade for higher-tier assets. Premium IAC can be earned within an app but the simplest way to acquire more is to purchase it.

In this article, we‚Äôre going to focus on Premium IAC. The name of your Simple currency has a much smaller impact on your business‚Äô bottom line.

Why? Because with Premium IAC the goal is to get your users to part with their real currency. There‚Äôs different mechanics that can be used to increase purchase behaviour, but would user‚Äôs rather buy ‚Äòpoints‚Äô to upgrade their towers or buy ‚Äògems‚Äô?

‚Ä¶Or would they rather purchase coins, cash, diamonds, doubloons, FarmCash, gems, gold, karma, RiotPoints or tokens (to name a few)?

By simply changing the names of Premium IAC in products we‚Äôve designed, we‚Äôve seen increases of over 50% revenue from currency purchases alone.

If we extrapolate this data, suddenly $10,000 becomes $15,000, all from a simple name change.

In light of this, we created a quick and simple tool dubbed the Currency pyramid to help us brainstorm and rank names for Premium IAC.

The Currency¬†Pyramid

There are 3 areas of focus in the currency pyramid:

  • Perceived Value
  • Perceived Loss
  • Perceived Novelty

Using gems as an example, we‚Äôll take a look through each of these areas and work through a few points of consideration for each.

Why gems? Gems are an all-round play it safe kinda name.

They fall short in a few cases, but more often they‚Äôre contextual ‚Äòenough‚Äô in almost any given scenario.

Perceived Value

Whether the currency is real or fabricated, it‚Äôll still follow the governing laws of perceived value.

Perceived value focuses on how much the user feels the currency is worth. Ultimately, the worth of a currency boils down to its buying power, how difficult it is to earn and (paradoxically) social proof.

If more people value and desire the currency, then it becomes infamous and inadvertently, as more people want it, the perceived value increases.

Perceived value is the same phenomenon that creates purchase behaviour.

If we perceive something as useful and valuable to our lives, then we‚Äôre willing to exchange resources to own/get access to it. The important thing to remember is that perceived value is subjective, so don‚Äôt expect everyone to ‚Äòfeel‚Äô the same way.

To maximise perceived value, focus on creating value for a specific audience (your app‚Äôs audience) rather than trying to please everyone, as that‚Äôll dilute the value proposition.

This is how we see the perceived value of gems (higher is better):

  • What is this currency worth to a user? 7/10
    Gems is an interesting name because it‚Äôs ambiguous. Gems could be precious (diamonds) or semi-precious (sapphire), there‚Äôs no real indication here of which, but either way, the name holds value. Gems are seen in films, TV shows and in everyday life as relatively sought after.
  • Is the currency challenging to earn? 7/10
    Again, since gems are ambiguous, it‚Äôs difficult to give an absolute indication, but overall the answer here is yes. The average person couldn‚Äôt find or dig up gems, they‚Äôd need to part with currency to find or acquire a real gem and have it polished etc.
  • How scarce is the currency? 7/10
    Quite scarce, gems tend to be present in the media more so than everyday life, but some gems go under the radar entirely. Most families possess a gem of some description, so at some stage, everyone should have had exposure.
  • Is the currency highly sought after? 7/10
    Gems are highly sought after as fashion accessories, gifts or as symbols of marriage. They‚Äôre likely to appear to a more female target audience than male, but without any data, that point is conjecture.

Overall perceived value = moderate (7/10)
This might seem harsh, but there‚Äôs definitely more valuable currency out there. Through the exploration, we‚Äôve already discovered that gems could be precious or semi-precious and more clarity on the type of gem (or a more suited context) would raise the perceived value here.

Perceived Loss

Perceived value and perceived loss are two sides of the same coin and often referred to as opportunity cost.

Opportunity cost is a simple concept, if you make one decision, what‚Äôre you giving up to fulfil that decision?

When you buy a new computer, the opportunity cost could be giving up on buying a new washing machine or going on holiday.

When you‚Äôre buying Premium IAC, you‚Äôre buying into a currency that can only be spent within an app, and on the assets within that app.

Most users can return a computer, or sell it on to recover some of the loss. With Premium IAC, it can‚Äôt be resold, it‚Äôs tied to you and you alone.

For the purchase of IAC to happen, there needs to be perceived value, but on the other side of the coin, what is the perceived loss? If the perceived loss is too great, but you‚Äôve managed to insight purchase behaviour, then users will feel a phenomenon known as buyer‚Äôs regret.

With buyer‚Äôs regret, users find themselves slowly loathing the purchase they‚Äôve made, deeming it as a poor choice.

Buyer‚Äôs regret temporarily reduces spending behaviour and leaves a lasting impression on the product that insight it (which is detrimental to a user‚Äôs lifetime value).

This is how we‚Äôd look at the perceived loss for gems (lower is better).

  • How does losing the currency feel? 7/10
    Because of the ambiguity of gems, it‚Äôs tricky to nail down an exact estimate. Losing diamonds would feel terrible, losing sapphire, not so much. Either way losing a gem is detrimental, they‚Äôre a finite resource and either as gifts or symbols, they‚Äôre still meaningful.
  • Is the loss memorable? 6/10
    There‚Äôs definitely worse things to lose than gems, but their slightly scarce and precious nature means the loss could be a detrimental one. In this instance, the obscurity plays in our favour.
  • What‚Äôre the side effects of the loss? 8/10
    Typically, gems aren‚Äôt cheap or easy to replace. They‚Äôre a scarce resource and you‚Äôd be hard pushed to replace sapphire, let alone diamond.
  • How difficult is balancing the loss? 6/10
    If the loss is memorable and detrimental, more mechanics will need to be in place to balance the loss. Since the idea of losing gems is ambiguous, the loss will need some balancing mechanics, but less than some other currencies.

Overall perceived loss = moderate (7/10)
The loss isn‚Äôt too dear, but it‚Äôs not unnoticeable, losing gems (precious or otherwise) will be a typically unpleasant ordeal. That being said, balancing the loss through a careful value proposition shouldn‚Äôt be too challenging.

Perceived Novelty

Novelty refers to how fun, memorable and easy to recall the currency is.

As users, we all seek fascination and excitement within our lives. When something is fascinating, our involvement with the object in question becomes greater. Even if this fascination is only short-lived, it leaves a lasting and memorable impression in our minds.

But fascination is only a small part of what novelty is and how it‚Äôs created.

If you‚Äôre looking for a strict definition of novelty‚Ä¶

Novelty is the quality of being new, original, or unusual.‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäCambridge Dictionary

Anything that can insight originality or the unusual can be defined as novel, which gives you a lot of flexibility on what you can do or what you can your Premium IAC.

This is how we‚Äôd look at perceived novelty for gems (higher is better).

  • Is there a strong recall value? 9/10
    Yes, although it‚Äôs not the most original name, most people are aware of what gems are and their use in this context. Since several apps already use gems, it‚Äôs unlikely users will struggle to recall the name here.
  • How unique is this currency? 3/10
    Unfortunately, gems isn‚Äôt a unique currency. It‚Äôs used frequently and it‚Äôs often the go-to for a lot of apps, as it has ambiguous contextual ties.
  • How familiar is this currency? 9/10
    Because of how gems are used in society (gifts, accessories, marriage symbols) they‚Äôre very familiar. Novelty doesn‚Äôt demand names be new or unique, elements of familiarity in novelty will increase user‚Äôs affinity.
  • Can the currency be easily visualised? 7/10
    Gems are synonymous with looking a certain way, so there are some boundaries to how much novelty can be exerted with visualisation here. But, there‚Äôs plenty of opportunities to flex your creative muscles and create cool looking gems.

Overall perceived novelty = moderate (7/10)
Gems have a high recall value and are familiar enough to users that with a clever design to symbolism gems, it‚Äôll be novel enough as a Premium IAC. There‚Äôs more novelty out there, but gems are a stable place to start.

The Perfect¬†Formula

In an ideal world, the name of your Premium IAC will look like the above.

There‚Äôll be little to no perceived loss, it‚Äôll have incredible perceived value and more than that, it‚Äôll be novel for users to buy and spend.

Truth is, there‚Äôs no name that can do the above on its own.

The experience, context and flow of the app will play a critical part in adding to and creating the perfect formula.

In fact, the experience itself has the potential to take any mundane name (like points) and push it towards the perfect balance.

That being said, time is alway against us as designers.

We could spend 4 weeks crafting an experience to see if we‚Äôve managed to tip the needle, or we can use the Currency Pyramid to increase overall revenue in as little as a day.

We use the pyramid to validate our thinking and come up with the best Premium IAC names we can think of and to optimise existing currencies in products.

After that, it‚Äôs always time to focus on the experience.
